astu: <entryFree id="n4192" type="greek" key="astu"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astu</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">asty</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 8, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7" default="NO" valid="yes">7</bibl> praef.), <gen>n.</gen>, indecl., = <foreign lang="greek">a)/stu</foreign>, <sense id="n4192.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">Athens</hi> (as urbs <foreign lang="greek">kat) e)coxh/n</foreign> for Rome): omnes qui arcem astuque accolunt cives, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 4, 330</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">An in astu venit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">demigrare ex agris et in astu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Alcib. 6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Alcib. 6, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astula: <entryFree id="n4193" type="main" key="astu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astŭla</orth>, v. assula.</entryFree>
astupeo: <entryFree id="n4194" type="main" key="astu^pe^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">a-stŭpĕo</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">ads-</orth>, Merk.), <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n4194.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be amazed at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">on account of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be astonished at</hi> (rare, and mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; <cit><quote lang="la">perh. not before the Aug. per.): Adstupet ipse sibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:418" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 418</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cui fida manus proceresque socerque Adstupet oranti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:406" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 406</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Tranq. Vit. 1:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Tranq. Vit. 1, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 5, 5</bibl>.—Of inanimate things: <cit><quote lang="la">nemus adstupet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:13" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
astur: <entryFree id="n4195" type="main" key="astur1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astur</orth>, <itype>ŭris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4195.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a species of hawk</hi>, Firm. Math. 5, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4196" type="main" key="Astur2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astur</orth>, <itype>ŭris</itype>, <sense id="n4196.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. m.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the province of Asturia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, <hi rend="ital">Asturian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:199" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 199</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Asturco: exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:252" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 252</bibl></cit>.—<pos>Subst.</pos>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an Asturian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">belliger Astur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:748" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 748</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regio Asturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 20, 34, § 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conventus Asturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 3, 4, § 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cantabri et Astures validissimae gentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:12:46" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 12, 46</bibl></cit> and 54.</sense></entryFree>
astura: <entryFree id="n4197" type="main" key="Astu^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astŭra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/astura</foreign>. <sense id="n4197.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Asturia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Esla</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:12:54" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 12, 54</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4197.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river</hi> (and <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an island and town</hi>) <hi rend="ital">in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near which Cicero had a villa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 57</bibl>; cf. Mann. Ital. I. p. 620.</sense></entryFree>
asturco: <entryFree id="n4198" type="main" key="Asturco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Asturco</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Astur</etym>, <sense id="n4198.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Asturian horse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an ambler</hi>, distinguished for the beautiful motion of its limbs (cf. the epigram, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:199" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 199</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:336" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 3, 336</bibl>), Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 81" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 81</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Equini generis, hi sunt quos thieldones vocamus, minore formā appellatos Asturcones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 67, § 166</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 2, 28, 37</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to other horses possessing similar qualities: <cit><quote lang="la">Asturco Macedonicus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 86</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
asturia: <entryFree id="n4199" type="main" key="Astu^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astŭrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n4199.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A province in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 20, 34, § 112</bibl>; cf. Mann. Hispan. p. 353 sq.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Astŭ-rĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Asturian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 67, § 166</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:16:584" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 16, 584</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4199.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Astŭrĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the capital of Asturia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the river Astura</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Astorga</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Asturica urbs magnifica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 3, 4, § 28</bibl></cit>; cf. Mann. Hispan. p. 355.</sense></entryFree>
astus: <entryFree id="n4200" type="main" key="astus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, v. astutus.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4201" type="main" key="astus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Curtius suggests the Sanscr. aksh = to reach, hit, and <foreign lang="greek">o)cu/s</foreign>, swift; and Vanicek, ascia and <foreign lang="greek">a)ci/nh</foreign>, with the idea of sharpness; others <foreign lang="greek">a)ske/w</foreign>, to practise</etym>, <sense id="n4201.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adroitness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dexterity;</hi> hence, in malam partem, <hi rend="ital">craft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cunning</hi> (as a single act, while <hi rend="ital">astutia</hi> designates cunning as a habit; until the post-Aug. period found only in the <case>abl.</case>, astu, as an <pos>adv.</pos>; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=5" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 5</bibl> Müll., and <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1012</bibl> P.): <cit><quote lang="la">Satin astu et fallendo callet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 197" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 197</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">Nisi ut astu ingenium linguā laudem et dictis lactem lenibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> p. 189: <cit><quote lang="la">nam doli non doli sunt, nisi astu colas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sed ut astu sum adgressus ad eas!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 123</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:4:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 4, 1, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. prol. 111</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">astu providere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">astu rem tractare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Consilio versare dolos ingressus et astu, Incipit haec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:704" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 704</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille astu subit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 522</bibl></cit>: aliquem <cb n="ASTU" /> astu adgredi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 64</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">astus belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:16:32" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 16, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio, quae astu caret, pondero modo et inpulsu proeliatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:1:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 1, 20</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">astus hostium in perniciem ipsis vertebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeveniens inimicorum astus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 44</bibl></cit>; 12, 45; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 97</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ulixes nectit pectore astus callidos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Troad. 527" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Troad. 527</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc advoca astus, anime, nunc fraudes, dolos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:ib. 618" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 618</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad insidiarum astus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:18:17" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 18, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
astusapes: <entryFree id="n4202" type="main" key="Astu^sa^pes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astŭsăpes</orth>, v. Astapus.</entryFree>
astute: <entryFree id="n4203" type="main" key="astu_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. astutus <sense id="n4203.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
astutia: <entryFree id="n4204" type="main" key="astu_ti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>astutus</etym>, <sense id="n4204.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality of</hi> being astutus, orig. (like acumen, dolus, etc.) <hi rend="ital">dexterity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adroitness</hi>, and also (eccl. Lat.) <hi rend="ital">understanding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wisdom</hi>: Quibus (feris) abest ad praecavendum intellegendi astutia, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:11:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 11, 31</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 122 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut detur parvulis astutia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intellegite, parvuli, astutiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 8, 5</bibl></cit>.—But very early used in a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">cunning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slyness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">subtlety</hi>, <hi rend="ital">craft</hi> as a habit (most freq. in ante-class. and Ciceron. Lat.; <cit><quote lang="la">afterwards supplanted by astus, q. v.): est nobis spes in hac astutiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec copiast [Me expediundi], nisi si astutiam aliquam corde machinor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 3, 15</bibl></cit> Fleck.; 3, 4, 7; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 2, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 82</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc opus est tuā Mihi ad hanc rem expromptā malitiā atque astutiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 3, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod si aut confidens astutia aut callida esset audacia, vix ullo obsisti modo posset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:65:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 65, 183</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae tamen non astutiā quādam, sed aliquā potius sapientiā secutus sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui (Deus) adprehendit sapientes in astutiā eorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 5, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Cor. 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ephes. 4, 14</bibl>.—Also <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">in regionem astutiarum mearum te induco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 78</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 2, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hem astutias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 4, 25</bibl></cit> Don.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliter leges, aliter philosophi tollunt astutias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:17:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 17, 68</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 17, 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astutulus: <entryFree id="n4205" type="hapax" key="astu_tu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4205.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">somewhat sly</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cunning</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, p. 184, 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
astutus: <entryFree id="n4206" type="main" key="astu_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>a lengthened form of the ante-class. astus, like versutus from versus, cinctutus from cinctus; and astus itself has the form of a <pos>P. a.</pos>, q. v. <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n4206.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">shrewd</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sagacious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">expert;</hi> or (more freq., cf. astutia) in mal. part., <hi rend="ital">sly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cunning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">designing</hi>, etc. * </sense><sense id="n4206.1" n="I" level="1"> Ante-class. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">astus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um: asta lingua, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 1, 54</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4206.2" n="II" level="1"> Class. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtus</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">malus, callidus, astutus admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Causam dicere adversus astutos, audacīs viros, valentes virgatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tam astutus, neque ita perspicax,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verum ego numquam adeo astutus fui, Quin etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 2, 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil astutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:19:64" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 19, 64</bibl></cit>: hoc celandi genus est hominis non aperti, non simplicis, non ingenui; <cit><quote lang="la">versuti potius, obscuri, astuti, fallacis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:13:57" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 13, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">astuti Getae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:5:44" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 5, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Parthorum astutae tela remissa fugae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:8:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 8, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut est astuta et ingeniosa sollertia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 26, 66, § 192</bibl></cit>, where Jan omits <hi rend="ital">astuta et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens non astuta, nec callida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 22</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">pro bene sano Ac non incauto fictum astutumque vocamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo sagax et astutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:88:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 88, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Est vir astutus multorum eruditor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:37:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 37, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulpes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:10 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 10 al.</bibl></cit>—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">Astutus omnia agit cum consilio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 13, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:18:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccli. 18, 28</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fallacia astutior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qui me astutiorem fingit (followed by callidius),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 8, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui custodit increpationes, astutior fiet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:15:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 15, 5</bibl></cit>.—* <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">astutissimus adversarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. 17" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. 17</bibl></cit>: astutissima calliditas, id. Civ. Dei, 21, 6.— <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">astūtē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">craftily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cunningly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">astute comminisci aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">docte atque astute captare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulte, docte atque astute cavere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 7, 14</bibl></cit>: Astute, <hi rend="ital">shrewdly</hi> done, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 2, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">astute labefactare aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">satis astute adgredi aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">astute reticere aliquid,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: astute nihil agere, Matius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 28, 3</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">astutius ponere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, 1</bibl></cit> Müll.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">astutissime componere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">astutissime excogitare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 22</bibl></cit>: astutissime fingi, Aug. Civ. Dei, 19, 5. <cb n="AT" /></sense></entryFree>
asty: <entryFree id="n4207" type="main" key="asty"><orth extent="full" lang="la">asty</orth>, v. astu.</entryFree>
astyages: <entryFree id="n4208" type="main" key="Asty^a^ges"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astyăges</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)astua/ghs</foreign>. <sense id="n4208.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">King of Media</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Mandane</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and grandfather of Cyrus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by whom he was deprived of his throne</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:4 sq" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 4 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4208.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An enemy of Perseus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">changed by him to stone by means of Medusa's head</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 203</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astyanax: <entryFree id="n4209" type="main" key="Asty^a^nax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astyănax</orth>, <itype>actis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)astua/nac</foreign> (<case>acc.</case> Gr. Astyanacta, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:457" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 457</bibl>). <sense id="n4209.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Hector and Andromache; at the destruction of Troy he was thrown from a tower by Ulysses</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:457" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 457</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:415" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 415</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n4209.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A tragic actor in the time of Cicero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:15:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 15, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astycus: <entryFree id="n4210" type="main" key="asty^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astycus</orth>, v. asticus.</entryFree>
astylos: <entryFree id="n4211" type="main" key="Asty^lo^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astylŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/astulos</foreign>, <sense id="n4211.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a centaur and soothsayer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who endeavored to dissuade the other centaurs from the war with the Lapithœ</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:308" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 308</bibl> (called by Hes. Scut. Herc. 185, <foreign lang="greek">*)/asbolos</foreign>).</sense></entryFree>
astypalaea: <entryFree id="n4212" type="main" key="Asty^pa^laea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astypălaea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)astupa/laia</foreign>. <sense id="n4212.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the Sporades</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an island near Crete</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Stampalia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:13" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 23, § 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 82</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4212.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4212.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Astypălaeenses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Astypalœa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:18:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 18, 45</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n4212.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Astypălaeĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Astypalœan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cochleae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 4, 11, § 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:45" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 6, 15, § 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:127" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 14, 43, § 127</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4212.4" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Asty-pălēĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>; a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> form for the preced., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:461" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 461</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astyra: <entryFree id="n4213" type="main" key="Asty^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Astyra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Astyrē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4213.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Mysia Major</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from Adramyttium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:18:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 18, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 32, § 122</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
astytis: <entryFree id="n4214" type="greek" key="asty^tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">astytis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)stuti/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4214.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of lettuce</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 38, § 127</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
asum: <entryFree id="n4215" type="main" key="Asum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Asum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n4215.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Crete</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 20, § 59</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
asyla: <entryFree id="n4216" type="greek" key="asy_la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">asȳla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)su/lh</foreign>, <sense id="n4216.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant;</hi> otherwise called ferus oculus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 92, § 145</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
asylum: <entryFree id="n4217" type="greek" key="a^sy_lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăsȳlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/sulon</foreign>, <sense id="n4217.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a place of refuge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sanctuary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an asylum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">servus, qui in illud asylum confugisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romulus asylum aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucum asylum referre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:342" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 342</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Junonis asylum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 761</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">asyla statuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucus asyli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: de asylo procedere, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:4:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 4, 34</bibl> al.</sense></entryFree>
asymbolus: <entryFree id="n4218" type="greek" key="a^symbo^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăsymbŏlus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">ăsum-</orth>, Fleck.), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)su/mbolos</foreign>, <sense id="n4218.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that contributes nothing to an entertainment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scot-free</hi> (in pure Lat., immunis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:12:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 12, 23</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">Tene asumbolum venire unctum atque lautum e balneis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 25</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 13</bibl> (opp.: <cit><quote lang="la">sumbolam dare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 61</bibl></cit>).</sense></entryFree>
asyndeton: <entryFree id="n4219" type="greek" key="a^synde^ton"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăsyndĕton</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)su/ndeton</foreign>, <sense id="n4219.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rhetorical figure by which the connecting particle is omitted</hi> (in pure Lat., dissolutio), e. g. Veni, vidi, vici; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 440</bibl> P.—<hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăsyndĕtus</orth>, <itype>a, um, in astronomy, of stars</itype>, <hi rend="ital">standing without any connection with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or reference to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a constellation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Mercurius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
at: <entryFree id="n4220" type="main" key="at"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ast</orth>, <sense id="n4220.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [Curtius connects the Sanscr. ati, ultra, nimis, the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/ti</foreign>, the Lat. et, and at in atavus; Vanicek connects with these at, atque, and atqui. Thus the original idea of <hi rend="ital">addition</hi> is prominent in <foreign lang="greek">e)/ti</foreign>, et, and atque; and the idea of <hi rend="ital">opposition</hi> in at and atqui, which agree with <foreign lang="greek">a)t-a/r</foreign> in meaning as well as in form. After the same analogy, the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ple/on</foreign>, more, has become <foreign lang="greek">plh/n</foreign>, but; and the Lat. magis has passed into the same meaning in the Fr. mais and the Ital. mai. The confusion in MSS. between at, ac, and et, and between atque and atqui, was prob. caused as much by their connection in idea as in form] (it was sometimes, for the sake of euphony, written ad; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:32" default="NO">12, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:5" default="NO">1, 7, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 203</bibl> P., where, instead of at conjunctionem esse, ad vero praepositionem, the reading should be, <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> conjunctionem esse, <hi rend="ital">at</hi> vero praepositionem, Fr.; v. the pass. in its connection; cf. also Vel. Long. p. 2230 P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> p. 2287</bibl> P.; Mar. Vict. p. 2458 P. The form ast is found in the old laws; it occurs once in Trag. Rel., but never in Com. Rel. nor in Lucil.; at is found in Plautus about 280 times, and ast about 10 times; in Ter. at about 100 times, and ast once; in Hor. at 60 times, ast 3 times; in Verg. at 168 times, ast 16; in Juv. at 17 times, ast 7; Catull., Tibull., and Prop. use only at, and Pers. (Jahn) only ast; in prose, Cic. uses <pb n="186" /> <cb n="AT" /> ast in his epistles. It joins to a previous thought a new one, either antithetical or simply different, and especially an objection; while <hi rend="ital">sed</hi> denotes a direct opposition; and <hi rend="ital">autem</hi> marks a transition, and denotes at once a connection and an opposition). </sense><sense id="n4220.1" n="I" level="1"> In adding a diff., but not entirely opp. thought, a qualification, restriction, etc., <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet;</hi> sometimes an emphasized (but never merely copulative) <hi rend="ital">and.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4220.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: SEI PARENTEM PVER VERBERIT AST OLE PLORASSIT PVER DIVEIS PARENTOM SACER ESTO, <hi rend="ital">if the son strike his father</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the father complain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">let the son</hi>, etc., Lex Serv. Tullii ap. Fest. s. v. plorare, p. 230 Müll.; Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 24</bibl>: Philosophari est mihi necesse, at paucis, <hi rend="ital">but only in a few words</hi>, Enn., Trag. Rel. p. 65 Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">DIVOS ET EOS QVI CAELESTES, SEMPER HABITI COLVNTO ... AST OLLA PROPTER QVAE etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:8:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 8, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 4, 11</bibl>: hinc Remus auspicio se devovet atque secundam Solus avem servat. At Romulus pulcer in alto Quaerit Aventino, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:48:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 48, 107</bibl> (Ann. v. 83 Vahl.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ego hic peribo, ast ille, ut dixit, non redit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 5, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paret Amor dictis carae genetricis. At Venus Ascanio placidam per membra quietem Inrigat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 691</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Aeneas) finem dedit ore loquendi. At, Phoebi nondum patiens, immanis in antro Bacchatur vates,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 77</bibl></cit>; 11, 709 sq.: quo (odore) totum nati corpus perduxit; <cit><quote lang="la">at illi Dulcis compositis spiravit crinibus aura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:416" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 416</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 460</bibl>; 4, 513; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 259</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 675</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 81</bibl>; 8, 241; 9, 793; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:4:15" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 4, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:7:11" default="NO">4, 7, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:664" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 664</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:36 al" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 36 al.</bibl>—Also in prose (chiefly post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">una (navis) cum Nasidianis profugit: at ex reliquis una praemissa Massiliam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi facta sunt, in unum omnia miscentur. At pastilli haec ratio est, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quamquam insideret urbem proprius miles, tres urbanae, novem praetoriae cohortes Etruriā ferme Umbriāque delectae aut vetere Latio et coloniis antiquitus Romanis. At apud idonea provinciarum sociae triremes etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">negavit aliā se condicione adlecturum, quam si pateretur ascribi albo, extortum sibi a matre. At illa commota etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:51" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vesp. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:7 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 7 al.</bibl>—In the enumeration of particulars: <cit><quote lang="la">Cum alio cantat, at tamen alii suo dat digito litteras, Naev., Com. Rel. p. 20 Rib.: dant alios aliae (silvae) fetus: dant utile lignum Navigiis pinos ... At myrtus validis hastilibus et bona bello Cornus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 447</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nam neque tum stellis acies obtunsa videtur ... At nebulae magis etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 401</bibl></cit>; 3, 87; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 7, 691</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hic altā Sicyone, ast hic Amydone relictā, Hic Andro, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:69" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 69</bibl></cit>.— The Vulg. often uses at as a mere continuative, where even et or atque might stand: sciscitabur ab iis ubi Christus nasceretur. At illi dixerunt ei: In etc., Matt. 2, 5; 4, 20; 8, 32; 14, 29; 15, 34 et persaep.—In transition, </sense><sense id="n4220.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., </sense><sense id="n4220.4" n="1" level="3"> To a new narration, like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">de/</foreign>; so the commencement of the fourth book of the Æneid: At regina gravi jam dudum saucia curā, etc. (the third book closes with the narrative of Æneas); so the beginning of the third book of the Thebaid of Statius: At non Aoniae moderator perfidus aulae, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:504" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 504</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 545</bibl>; 5, 700; 5, 779; 6, 679; 7, 5; 8, 370; 8, 608; 9, 503; 10, 689; 11, 597; 12, 134 et saep.—Also in the postAug. histt. and other prose writers; so after speaking of the Ubii etc., Tac. says: At in Chaucis coeptavere seditionem praesidium agitantes etc., A. 1, 38; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 62</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 23</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n4220.5" n="2" level="3"> To a wonderful, terrible, unexpected, or exciting occurrence or circumstance: <cit><quote lang="la">clamores simul horrendos ad sidera tollit, etc. ... At gemini lapsu delubra ad summa dracones Effugiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:225" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 225</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 225</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lacte madens illic suberat Pan ilicis umbrae, Et facta agresti lignea falce Pales etc. At quā Velabri regio patet etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:33" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:471" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 471</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">consurgit Turnus in ensem et ferit. Exclamant Troes trepidique Latini, Arrectaeque amborum acies. At perfidus ensis Frangitur in medio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:731" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 12, 731</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">10, 763</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adusque Supremum tempus, ne se penuria victūs Opprimeret metuebat. At hunc liberta securi divisit medium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 99</bibl></cit>: Magnus quanto mucrone minatur Noctibus hibernis et sidera<cb n="AT" />  terret Orion. At sonipes habitus etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:1:46" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 1, 46</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.6" n="3" level="3"> To a passionate appeal, etc., in which case the antecedent clause is not expressed, but must be considered as existing in the mind of the speaker; cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)lla\ su/, su\ de/</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n4220.7" n="a" level="4"> In passing to an interrogation, exhortation, request: <cit><quote lang="la">At, scelesta, viden ut ne id quidem me dignum esse existumat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 2, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 1, 1, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At qui nummos tristis inuncat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:15:21" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> 15, 21</bibl></cit> Müll.: <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> Sauream non novi. <hi rend="ital">Li.</hi> At nosce sane, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:4:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 4, 58</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ca.</hi> Non adest. <hi rend="ital">Ps.</hi> At tu cita, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">satis habeo, at quaeso hercle etiam vide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 5, 4, 53</bibl></cit> (Ritschl, <hi rend="ital">sat habeo. Sed</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">at unum hoc quaeso ... Ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at tu, qui laetus rides mala nostra caveto Mox tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:2:87" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 2, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hunc ut Peleus vidit, At inferias, juvenum gratissime Crantor, Accipe, ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:367" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 367</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at tu, nauta, vagae ne parce malignus arenae Ossibus et capiti inhumato Particulam dare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:28:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 28, 23</bibl></cit>.—In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">at vide quid succenseat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:24:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 24, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque pulsus ego civitate non sum, quae nulla erat: at vide, quam ista tui latrocinii tela contempserim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:4:1:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. Or. 4, 1, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 44</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, p. 179, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.8" n="b" level="4"> In expressions of passion, astonishment, indignation, pain, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">At ut scelesta sola secum murmurat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 1, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Sc.</hi> Nunc quidem domi certost: certa res est Nunc nostrum opservare ostium, [ubi] ubist. <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> At, Sceledre, quaeso, Ut etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:4:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 4, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At o deorum quidquid in caelo regit Terras et humanum genus, Quid iste fert tumultus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:1" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi quanta domus rutila testudine fulgens, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:4:11" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 4, 11</bibl></cit>.—In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">horum omnium studium una mater oppugnat: at quae mater?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 70</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at per deos immortales! quid est, quod de hoc dici possit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">institui senatores, qui omnia indicum responsa perscriberent. At quos viros!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 42</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:19:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 19, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tangit et ira deos: at non impune feremus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 279</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">10, 724</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at tibi Colchorum, memini, regina vacavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 12, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.9" n="c" level="4"> In indignant imprecations: <cit><quote lang="la">At te di omnes cum consilio, Calve, mactāssint malo! Pomp., Com. Rel. p. 245 Rib.: At te Juppiter diique omnes perdant!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 1, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At te di deaeque faxint cum isto odio, Laches,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At te di perdant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 1, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi di dignum factis exitium duint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 4, 1, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At vobis male sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi, pro scelere, exclamat, pro talibus ausis Di ... persolvant grates dignas et praemia reddant Debita!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:535" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 535</bibl></cit>.—In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">At vos, ait, devota capita, respiciant di perjuriorum vindices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:14:4:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 14, 4, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.10" n="d" level="4"> Rarely of friendly inclination, disposition: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi di bene faciant omnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 3, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi di semper, adulescens, quisquis es, faciant bene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 7, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tu, Catulle, destinatus obdura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 8, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.11" n="e" level="4"> In entreaty: <cit><quote lang="la">At vos, o superi, miserescite regis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:572" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 572</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at tu, pater deūm hominumque, hinc saltem arce hostes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.12" n="II" level="1"> In adding an entirely opposite thought, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but on the other hand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the contrary</hi>, etc. (the strictly class. signif. of the word). </sense><sense id="n4220.13" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <hi rend="ital">at</hi> differentiam rerum significat: ut cum dicimus, Scipio est bellator, at M. Cato orator, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=11" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 11</bibl> Müll.: splendet saepe, ast idem nimbis interdum nigret, Att., Trag. Rel. p. 170 Rib.: <hi rend="ital">So.</hi> Mentire nunc. <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> At jam faciam, ut verum dicas dicere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:189" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 189</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">So.</hi> Per Jovem juro med etc. <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> At ego per Mercurium juro, tibi etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 280</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque oppido hercle bene velle illud visus sum, Ast non habere quoi commendarem caprum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fecit idem Themistocles ... at idem Pericles non fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 11, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non placet M. Antonio consulatus meus, at placuit P. Servilio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">majores nostri Tusculanos Aequos ... in civitatem etiam acceperunt, at Karthaginem et Numantiam funditus sustulerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 11, 35</bibl></cit>: brevis a naturā nobis vita data est; <cit><quote lang="la">at memoria bene redditae vitae sempiterna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:12:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 14, 12, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">crebras a nobis litteras exspecta, ast plures etiam ipse mittito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: Rejectis pilis comminus gladiis pugnatum est. At Germani phalange factā impetus gladiorum exceperunt, Caes. <cb n="AT" /> B. G. 1, 52: <cit><quote lang="la">Postquam Caesar dicendi finem fecit, ceteri verbo alius alii varie adsentiebantur. At M. Porcius Cato hujusce modi orationem habuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hac iter Elysium nobis, at laeva ... ad impia Tartara mittit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:542" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 542</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">T.</hi> Ante leves ergo pascentur in aethere cervi ... <hi rend="ital">M.</hi> At nos hinc alii sitientīs ibimus Afros, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 1, 65</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Dam.</hi> Malo me Galatea petit, lasciva puella ... <hi rend="ital">Men.</hi> At mihi sese offert ultro meus ignis Amyntas, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 66</bibl>; 7, 35; 7, 55; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:219" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 219</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 242</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 370</bibl>; 2, 151; 2, 184; 3, 331; 4, 18; 4, 180; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 687</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 424</bibl>; 5, 264; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 489: Ast ego nutrici non mando vota,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:2:39" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 2, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ast illi tremat etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:6:74" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ast vocat officium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:6:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At Jesus audiens ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:9:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 9, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">9, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 3</bibl>; 12, 48 et persaep.—</sense><sense id="n4220.14" n="a" level="4"> In order to strengthen a contrast, sometimes (esp. in Plaut. and Ter.) with <hi rend="ital">contra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">e contrario</hi>, <hi rend="ital">potius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vero.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4220.15" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">contra</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Summis nitere opibus, at ego contra ut dissimilis siem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:26:19" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> 26, 19</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">Ergo quod magnumst aeque leviusque videtur ... At contra gravius etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:366" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 366</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:570" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 570</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:1087" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 1087</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:235" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 235</bibl>: L. Opimius ejectus est e patriā: At contra bis Catilina absolutus <hi rend="ital">est</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 95</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quinct. 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At tibi contra Evenit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Cornutus) taedio curarum mortem in se festinavit: at contra reus nihil infracto animo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 28</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.16" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">e contrario</hi>: apud nos mercenarii scribae existimantur; <cit><quote lang="la">at apud illos e contrario nemo ad id officium admittitur, nisi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in locis siccis partibus sulcorum imis disponenda sunt semina, ut tamquam in alveolis maneant. At uliginosis e contrario in summo porcae dorso collocanda, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:3:44" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 3, 44</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.17" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">potius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">at satius fuerat eam viro dare nuptum potius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at potius serves nostram, tua munera, vitam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:3:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 3, 149</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.18" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi>: At etiam, furcifer, Male loqui mi audes? <hi rend="ital">but do you even?</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:151" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 151</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At etiam cubat cuculus. Surge, amator, i domum,</quote> <trans><tr>but he is yet abed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 2, 73</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 3, 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Exi foras, sceleste. At etiam restitas, Fugitive!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 4, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 6, 10</bibl>: Proinde aut exeant, aut quiescant, etc. ... at etiam sunt, Quirites, qui dicant, a me in exsilium ejectum esse Catilinam, <hi rend="ital">on the contrary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">there are indeed people who say.</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 6, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:30:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 30, 76</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quinct. 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 77</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:70 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 70 al.</bibl>—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">vero</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but certainly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">At vero aut honoribus aucti aut etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:36:87" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 36, 87</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:20:70" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 20, 70</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 23, 80</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:10:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 10, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:17 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 17 al.</bibl>—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">certe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numquam ego te, vitā frater amabilior, Aspiciam posthac. At certe semper amabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:65:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 65, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:66:25" default="NO" valid="yes">66, 25</bibl>. —（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) So, quidem—at (very rare) = quidem —autem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:22:75" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 22, 75</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.19" n="b" level="4"> Ironically: <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Quid valeam? <hi rend="ital">Ly.</hi> At tu aegrota, si lubet, per me aetatem quidem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 3, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at, credo, mea numina tandem Fessa jacent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:297" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 297</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 363</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 44</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.20" n="B" level="2"> Very freq. in adding an objection, from one's own mind or another's, against an assertion previously made, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the contrary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in opposition to this;</hi> sometimes, <hi rend="ital">but one may say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it may be objected</hi>, and the like: <cit><quote lang="la">Piscium magnam atque altilium vim interfecisti. At nego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:28:43" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> 28, 43</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid tandem te impedit? Mosne majorum? At persaepe etiam privati in hac re publicā perniciosos cives morte multārunt. An leges, quae de civium Romanorum supplicio rogatae sunt? At numquam in hac urbe etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:11:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 11, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Appellandi tempus non erat? At tecum plus annum vixit. In Galliā agi non potuit? At et in provinciā jus dicebatur et etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quinct. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Male judicavit populus. At judicavit. Non debuit. At potuit. Non fero. At multi clarissimi cives tulerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt, quos signa, quos caelatum argentum delectant. At sumus, inquiunt, civitatis principes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:5:2:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. Or. 5, 2, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:25:71" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 25, 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid porro quaerendum est? Factumne sit? At constat: A quo? At patet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 6, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 9</bibl>: convivium vicinorum cotidie compleo, quod ad multam noctem, quam maxime possumus, vario sermone producimus. At non est voluptatum tanta quasi titillatio in senibus. Credo: sed ne desideratio quidem, <pb n="187" /> <cb n="AT" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:14:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 14, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo magnus orator praestat minutis imperatoribus. At prodest plus imperator. Quis negat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:73:256" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 73, 256</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:29:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 29, 62</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 31, 67</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 32, 69 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Maxime Juppiter! At in se Pro quaestu sumptum facit hic,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:18 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 18 al.</bibl></cit>— In this case freq. strengthened, </sense><sense id="n4220.21" n="a" level="4"> By <hi rend="ital">pol</hi>, <hi rend="ital">edepol</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hercule</hi>: At pol ego neque florem neque flocces volo mihi, Caecil., Com. Rel. p. 67 Rib.: <hi rend="ital">So.</hi> Non edepol volo profecto. <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> At pol profecto ingratiis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 215</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 2, 2, 34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 4, 2, 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 73</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ha.</hi> Gaudio ero vobis. <hi rend="ital">Ad.</hi> At edepol nos voluptati tibi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 61</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 1, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At hercule aliquot annos populus Romanus maximā parte imperii caruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 54</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at hercle in eā controversiā, quae de Argis est, superior sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At, Hercule, reliquis omnibus etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 50, 51, § 169</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At, hercules, Diodorus et in morbo etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 6, 39, § 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At hercule Germanicum Druso ortum etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 26</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 54: At, hercules, si conscius fuissem etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:10:20 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 10, 20 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n4220.22" n="b" level="4"> By <hi rend="ital">enim</hi>, which introduces a reason for the objection implied in at, <hi rend="ital">but certainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but surely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but indeed</hi>, etc., <foreign lang="greek">a)lla\ ga/r</foreign>: At enim tu nimis spisse incedis, Naev., Com. Rel. p. 16 Rib.; Turp. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:page=93" default="NO"><author>id.</author> p. 93</bibl>: at enim nimis hic longo sermone utimur; <cit><quote lang="la">Diem conficimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:3:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 3, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim istoc nil est magis etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim vereor, inquit Crassus, ne haec etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:49:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 49, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum dixisset Sophocles, O puerum pulchrum, Pericle. At enim praetorem, Sophocle, decet non solum manus, sed etiam oculos abstinentes habere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:40:144" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 40, 144</bibl></cit> Beier; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:35:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 35, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:17:52 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 17, 52 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at enim inter hos ipsos existunt graves controversiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quinct. 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:17:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 17, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">20, 60</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 17, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim cur a me potissimum hoc praesidium petiverunt?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Div. in Caecil. 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim quis reprehendet, quod in parricidas rei publicae decretum erit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 25</bibl></cit> Kritz: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim quid ita solus ego circum curam ago?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:32" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">At enim eo foedere, quod etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:31" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:37" default="NO" valid="yes">39, 37</bibl>: At enim nova nobis in fratrum filias conjugia; <cit><quote lang="la">sed etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.23" n="c" level="4"> By <hi rend="ital">tamen</hi>: Jam id peccatum primum magnum, <hi rend="ital">magnum</hi>, at humanum tamen, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 53</bibl>: Hi secretis sermonibus ... conveniunt; <cit><quote lang="la">nam publice civitas talibus inceptis abhorrebat. At tamen interfuere quidam etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">At certe tamen, inquiunt, quod etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:10:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 10, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.24" n="C" level="2"> With a preced. negative, sometimes no antithesis is appended by <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, but it is indicated that if what has been said is not true, yet at least something else is true, <hi rend="ital">but yet;</hi> sometimes with <hi rend="ital">tamen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but yet;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">certe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but at least</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet at least</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nolo victumas: at minimis me extis placare volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Si tibi non cordi fuerant conubia nostra, ... At tamen in vostras potuisti ducere sedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:158 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 158 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non cognoscebantur foris, at domi: non ab alienis, at a suis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 11, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Liceat haec nobis, si oblivisci non possumus, at tacere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 25, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Si genus humanum et mortalia temnitis arma, At sperate deos memores fandi atque nefandi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:543" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 543</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 615</bibl>, and 6, 406. —With <hi rend="ital">certe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Haec erant ... quorum cognitio studiosis juvenibus si non magnam utilitatem adferet, at certe, quod magis petimus, bonam voluntatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:31" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 12</bibl>, al.—</sense><sense id="n4220.25" n="D" level="2"> The antithesis is sometimes not so much in the clause appended by <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, as in the persons or things introduced in it; so, </sense><sense id="n4220.26" n="(a)" level="5"> Esp. freq. in conditional clauses with <hi rend="ital">si</hi>, <hi rend="ital">si non</hi>, <hi rend="ital">si minus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">etiam si</hi>, etc.; cf. Herm. ad Viger. 241: Si ego hic peribo, ast ille, ut dixit, non redit; At erit mi hoc factum mortuo memorabile, <hi rend="ital">if I perish here</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but he does not return</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 131</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ego digna hac contumeliā Sum maxime, at tu indignus qui faceres tamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Si tu oblitus es, at di meminerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:30:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 30, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si non eo die, at postridie,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si non paulo, at aliquanto (post petīsses),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:93 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 93 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quanta tempestas invidiae nobis, si minus in praesens, at in posteritatem impendeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 15</bibl>: qui non possit, etiam si sine <cb n="ATAL" /> ullā suspitione, at non sine argumento male dicere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 3, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.27" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">etsi</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ei, etsi nequāquam parem illius ingenio, at pro nostro tamen studio meritam gratiam referamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 4, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.28" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">quod si</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod si nihil cum potentiore juris humani relinquitur inopi, at ego ad deos confugiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 67</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.29" n="E" level="2"> At, like autem and <foreign lang="greek">de/</foreign>, sometimes serves simply to introduce an explanation: cum Sic mutilus miniteris. At illi foeda cicatrix etc., <hi rend="ital">now an ugly scar</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 60</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n4220.30" n="F" level="1"> And also like <foreign lang="greek">de/</foreign> in Hom. and Hdt., it sometimes introduces an apodosis, </sense><sense id="n4220.31" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">si</hi>: Bellona, si hobie nobis victoriam duis, ast ego templum tibi voveo, <hi rend="ital">if to-day thou bestow victory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then I</hi> etc., <foreign lang="greek">e)a/n</foreign>—<foreign lang="greek">de/</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4220.32" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">quoniam</hi>: Nunc, quoniam tuum insanabile ingenium est, at tu tuo supplicio doce etc., <hi rend="ital">since your disposition is past cure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at least</hi> etc., <foreign lang="greek">e)pei/</foreign>—<foreign lang="greek">de/</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 28</bibl>.!*? </sense><sense id="n4220.33" n="A" level="2"> At is sometimes repeated at the beginning of several clauses, </sense><sense id="n4220.34" n="a" level="4"> In opposition each to the preceding clause: <hi rend="ital">Soph.</hi> Tu quidem haut etiam octoginta's pondo. <hi rend="ital">Paegn.</hi> At confidentiā Militia illa militatur multo magis quam pondere. At ego hanc operam perdo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:2:47 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 2, 2, 47 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Si ego hic peribo, ast ille, ut dixit, non redit: At erit mi hoc factum mortuo memorabile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:25 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 25 sq.</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 2, 6</bibl> sqq. (Cic., in Quir. 7 and 10, opposes <hi rend="ital">at</hi> to <hi rend="ital">sed</hi>, and Tac., in A. 12, 6, <hi rend="ital">sed</hi> to <hi rend="ital">at</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n4220.35" n="b" level="4"> In opposition to some common clause preceding: <cit><quote lang="la">At etiam asto?
