Test. 1 Cor. 15, 52, but rendered <hi rend="ital">in momento</hi> by the Vulg.</sense></entryFree>
atque: <entryFree id="n4275" type="main" key="atque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atque</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">āc</orth> (atque is used before vowels and consonants, ac, in class. lang., only before consonants; <sense id="n4275.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>, I.), <hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [at has regularly in the compound atque a continuative, as in atqui it has an adversative force; pr. and further, and besides, and also; cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pro\s de/, pro\s de\ e)/ti, e)/ti kai/, e)/ti de/</foreign>, and <foreign lang="greek">te\ kai/</foreign>; v. at <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>, and for the change of form atque, ac, cf. neque, nec; in MSS. and inscriptions sometimes written <orth extent="full" lang="la">adque</orth>, and sometimes by confusion <orth extent="full" lang="la">at-qui</orth>], a copulative particle, <hi rend="ital">and also</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and</hi> (indicating a close internal connection between single words or whole clauses; while <hi rend="ital">et</hi> designates an external connection of diff. objects with each other, v. et; syn.: et, -que, autem, praeterea, porro, ad hoc, ad haec). </sense><sense id="n4275.1" n="I" level="1"> In joining single words, which is its most common use. </sense><sense id="n4275.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen. (The following representation is based on a collection of all the instances of the use of atque and ac in Cic. Imp. Pomp., Phil. 2, Tusc. 1, and Off. 1; in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1</bibl> and 2; in Sall. C.; and in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21</bibl>; and wherever in the account either author or work is not cited, there atque or ac does not occur.) </sense><sense id="n4275.3" n="1" level="3"> The form <orth extent="full" lang="la">atque</orth>. </sense><sense id="n4275.4" n="a" level="4"> Before vowels and <hi rend="ital">h.</hi>—Before <hi rend="ital">a</hi> (very freq.): <cit><quote lang="la">sociorum atque amicorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. G. 1, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inconsulte ac veluti etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 42:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 42, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opera ac vineae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:22" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:40" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 40</bibl>; 21, 43. —(So in the phrases treated below: atque adeo, atque alter or alius, atque eccum, atque eo, atque etiam, atque illuc, atque is or hic, atque iterum, atque omnia, atque ut, atque late, atque sic, atque velut, but ac ne, ac si, and ac tamen).—With <hi rend="ital">simul</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Britannorum acies in speciem simul ac terrorem editioribus locis constiterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in se simul atque in Herculem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suos prosequitur simul ac deponit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 30</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">sociis pariter atque hostibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">innocentes ac noxios juxta cadere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 48</bibl></cit>.—Hence, sometimes syn. with <hi rend="ital">et—et</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ut—ita</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aeque ac; both—and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as—so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as well—as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as well as</hi>: hodie sero ac nequiquam<pb n="190" /> <cb n="ATQU" />  voles, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 103</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:25:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 25, 79</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">verum et sero et nequidquam pudet): copia sententiarum atque verborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:19:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 19, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia honesta atque inhonesta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 30:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 30, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobiles atque ignobiles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 20:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 20, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caloris ac frigoris patientia par,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:41" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:127" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 127</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir bonus et prudens dici delector ego ac tu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.7" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4275.8" n="a" level="4"> In a hendiadys: <cit><quote lang="la">utinam isto animo atque virtute in summā re publicā versari quam in municipali maluisset,</quote> <trans><tr>with this virtuous feeling</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:16:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 16, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de conplexu ejus ac sinu,</quote> <trans><tr>of his bosom embrace</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:10:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 10, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me eadem, quae ceteros, fama atque invidia vexabat, i. e. invidiosa fama,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clamore atque adsensu,</quote> <trans><tr>shout of applause</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.9" n="b" level="4"> In joining to the idea of a preceding word one more important, <hi rend="ital">and indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and especially</hi> (v. Kritz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 4, 3</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n4275.10" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Absol.: Pa.</hi> Nempe tu istic ais esse erilem concubinam? <hi rend="ital">Sc.</hi> Atque arguo me etc., <hi rend="ital">yea and I maintain that I</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 3, 66</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ph.</hi> Tun vidisti? <hi rend="ital">Sc.</hi> Atque his quidem oculis, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 15</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ps.</hi> Ecquid habet is homo aceti in pectore? <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Atque acidissimi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 49</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 2, 40</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Py.</hi> Cognoscitne (ea)? <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Ac memoriter, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Faciam boni tibi aliquid pro istā re ac lubens,</quote> <trans><tr>and with a good will</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 5, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem difficilem (dii immortales) atque omnium difficillimam,</quote> <trans><tr>and indeed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:16:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 16, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna diis immortalibus habenda est gratia atque huic ipsi Jovi Statori, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>and especially</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hebeti ingenio atque nullo,</quote> <trans><tr>and in fact</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:15:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 15, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex plurimis periculis et insidiis atque ex mediā morte,</quote> <trans><tr>and even</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fratre meo atque eodem propinquo suo interfecto,</quote> <trans><tr>and at the same time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intra moenia atque in sinu urbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 52, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.11" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">adeo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and that too</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and even</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">intra moenia atque adeo in senatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in urbe remanserunt atque adeo qui contra urbis salutem etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 12, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insto atque urgeo, insector, posco atque adeo flagito crimen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non petentem atque adeo etiam absentem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 5</bibl></cit>.—And with <hi rend="ital">autem</hi> also added: <cit><quote lang="la">atque adeo autem quor etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:4:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 4, 42</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.12" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">id jam populare atque etiam plausibile factum est,</quote> <trans><tr>and also</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne Verginio commeatum dent atque etiam in custodiā habeant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 46</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.13" n="(d)" level="5"> With the <hi rend="ital">dem. pron.</hi> hic, is: <cit><quote lang="la">negotium magnum est navigare atque id mense Quintili,</quote> <trans><tr>and besides</tr>, <tr>and that</tr>, <tr>and that too</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">maximis defixis trabibus atque eis praeacutis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Asseres pedum XII. cuspidibus praefixis atque hi maximis ballistis missi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duabus missis subsidio cohortibus a Caesare, atque his primis legionum duarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 5, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flumen uno omnino loco pedibus atque hoc aegre transiri potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad celeritatem onerandi subductionesque paulo facit humiliores ... atque id eo magis, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. without id (perh. to avoid the repetition of the pron.): quā (sc. virtute) nostri milites facile superabant, atque eo magis, quod, etc., <hi rend="ital">and</hi> that <hi rend="ital">the more because</hi> etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 8</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicendi artem aptā trepidatione occultans atque eo validior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 69</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 46</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.14" n="II" level="1"> In comparisons. </sense><sense id="n4275.15" n="A" level="2"> Of equality (Rudd. II. p. 94; Zumpt, § 340); with par, idem, item, aequus, similis, juxta, talis, totidem, etc., <hi rend="ital">as</hi>: et nota, quod ex hujus modi structurā Graecā (sc. <foreign lang="greek">o(/moios kai/</foreign>, etc.) frequenter Latini ac et atque in significatione similitudinis accipiunt, Prisc. pp. 1192 and 1193 P.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 29</bibl>; Lidd. and Scott, s. v. <foreign lang="greek">kai/</foreign>, III.: <cit><quote lang="la">si parem sententiam hic habet ac formam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:6:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 6, 36</bibl></cit>: quom opulenti loquuntur pariter atque ignobiles, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ecastor pariter hoc atque alias res soles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pariter nunc operā me adjuves ac re dudum opitulata es,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque enim mihi par ratio cum Lucilio est ac tecum fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parique eum atque illos imperio esse jussit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magistrum equitum pari ac dictatorem imperio fugavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hann. 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pariter patribus ac plebi carus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 33</bibl></cit>: nam et vita est eadem et animus te erga idem ac fuit, Ter. <cb n="ATQU" /> Heaut. 2, 3, 24: <cit><quote lang="la">In hanc argumentationes ex eisdem locis sumendae sunt atque in causam negotialem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:23:70" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 23, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equi quod alii sunt ad rem militarem idonei, alii ad vecturam ... non item sunt spectandi atque habendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:7:15" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 7, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 10:section=74" default="NO"><author>id.</author> L. L. 10, § 74</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ex provinciā populi Romani aequam partem tu tibi sumpseris atque populo Romano miseris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Modo ne in aequo (jure) hostes apud vos sint ac nos socii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 37</bibl></cit> (exs. with aeque; v. aeque, <foreign lang="greek">d</foreign>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 83 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">et simili jure tu ulcisceris patrui mortem atque ille persequeretur fratris sui, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">similem pavorem inde ac fugam fore, ac bello Gallico fuerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:7:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 7, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">contendant, se juxta hieme atque aestate bella gerere posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:54:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 54, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">faxo eum tali mactatum, atque hic est, infortunio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:9:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 9, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 4, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum totidem navibus atque erat profectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 7, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.16" n="B" level="2"> Of difference; with alius and its derivv., with dissimile, contra, contrarius, secus, etc., <hi rend="ital">than</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illi sunt alio ingenio atque tu,</quote> <trans><tr>other than</tr>, <tr>different from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:35 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 35 al.</bibl></cit>; v. the passages under alius, I. B. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliter tuum amorem atque est accipis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:23 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 23 al.</bibl></cit>; v. the passages under aliter, 1. a.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">also aliorsum, II., and aliusmodi: quod est non dissimile atque ire in Solonium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simulacrum in excelso collocare et, contra atque ante fuerat, ad orientem convertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 8, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vides, omnia fere contra ac dicta sint evenisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui versantur retro, contrario motu atque caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:17:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 17, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">membra paulo secus a me atque ab illo partita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:30:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 30, 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus ego salutem non secus ac meam tueri debeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> al.; v. contra, contrarius, secus, etc.— </sense><sense id="n4275.17" n="C" level="2"> Sometimes, in cases of equality or difference, atque with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or ac with <hi rend="ital">si</hi> (with aliter affirm. Cic. appears to connect only atque ut, not ac si; <cit><quote lang="la">once, however, non aliter, ac si,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 51</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. aliter, 1. b.): pariter hoc fit atque ut alia facta sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:4:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 4, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec fallaciam Astutiorem ullus fecit poëta atque Ut haec est fabre facta a nobis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 5, 1, 6</bibl></cit> sqq.: <cit><quote lang="la">quod iste aliter atque ut edixerat decrevisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et qui suos casus aliter ferunt atque ut auctores aliis ipsi fuerunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:30:73" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 30, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si mentionem fecerint, quo aliter ager possideretur atque ut ex legibus Juliis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 18, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">16, 13</bibl>, c; cf. Wopk. Lect. Tull. 1, 15, p. 118; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:13:11" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 43, 13, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Egnatii absentis rem ut tueare, aeque a te peto ac si mea negotia essent,</quote> <trans><tr>just as if</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu autem similiter facis ac si me roges, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:3:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquis officiis, juxta ac si meus frater esset, sustentavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Post. Red. in Sen. 8, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod dandum est amicitiae, large dabitur a me non secus ac si meus esset frater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec sunt, tribuni, consilia vestra, non, hercule, dissimilia, ac si quis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> al. —</sense><sense id="n4275.18" n="D" level="2"> More rare with nimis, in partem, pro eo, etc.; <cit><quote lang="la">in Plaut. also with mutare or demutare = aliud esse: nimis bellus, atque ut esse maxume optabam, locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 4, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud centensumam Partem dixi atque, otium rei si sit, possim expromere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 168</bibl></cit>: sane quam pro eo ac debui graviter molesteque tuli, <hi rend="ital">just as was my duty</hi>, Sulp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">debeo sperare, omnes deos, qui huic urbi praesident, pro eo mihi, ac mereor, relaturos gratiam esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pro eo, ac si concessum sit, concludere oportebit argumentationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:32:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 32, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non possum ego non aut proxime atque ille aut etiam aeque laborare,</quote> <trans><tr>nearly the same as he</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 13, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque se luna quoquam mutat atque uti exorta est semel,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num quid videtur demutare atque ut quidem Dixi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 3, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.19" n="E" level="2"> Sometimes the word indicating comparison (aeque, tantopere, etc.) is to be supplied from the connection (in the class. per. perh. used only once by Cassius in epist. style): <cit><quote lang="la">nebula haud est mollis atque hujus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:4:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 4, 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem esse amicum ratus sum atque ipsus sum mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 6, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae suco caret atque putris pumex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1103,001:32:7" default="NO"><author>Priap.</author> 32, 7</bibl></cit> (Müll., <hi rend="ital">est putusque</hi>): digne ac mereor commendatus esse, Cass. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:14:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 14, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19" default="NO">19</bibl>, <cb n="ATQU" /> 2, 54.—</sense><sense id="n4275.20" n="F" level="1"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> or in post-Aug. prose with comparatives (for quam), <hi rend="ital">than</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicior mihi nullus vivit atque is est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 5, 2, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non Apollinis magis verum atque hoc responsum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 15</bibl></cit> Ruhnk.: <cit><quote lang="la">Illi non minus ac tibi Pectore uritur intimo Flamma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:61:172" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 61, 172</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud minus ac jussi faciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:561" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 561</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non tuus hoc capiet venter plus ac meus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 46</bibl></cit> Bentl. and Heind. (cf. infra: <cit><quote lang="la">nihilo plus accipias quam Qui nil portārit): qui peccas minus atque ego,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Artius atque hedera procera adstringitur ilex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:15:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 15, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 14</bibl> Ruhnk. —</sense><sense id="n4275.21" n="G" level="1"> In the comparison of two periods of time, most freq. with <hi rend="ital">simul</hi> (v. examples under simul); ante- or post-class. with <hi rend="ital">principio</hi>, <hi rend="ital">statim</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">principio Atque animus ephebis aetate exiit,</quote> <trans><tr>as soon as</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 1, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judici enim, statim atque factus est, omnium rerum officium incumbit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:25" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 21, 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quamvis, statim atque intercessit, mulier competierat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:1:24" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 16, 1, 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.22" n="III" level="1"> To connect a negative clause which explains or corrects what precedes; hence sometimes with <hi rend="ital">potius</hi> (class.; in Cic. very freq., but rare in the poets), <hi rend="ital">and not</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and not rather.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4275.23" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Decipiam ac non veniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si fidem habeat, ... ac non id metuat, ne etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perparvam vero controversiam dicis, ac non eam, quae dirimat omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:20:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 20, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi nunc id agatur, quis ex tantā multitudine occiderit, ac non hoc quaeratur, eum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si (mundum) tuum ac non deorum immortalium domicilium putes, nonne plane desipere videare?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:6:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo erat, qui illum reum ac non miliens condemnatum arbitraretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si hoc dissuadere est, ac non disturbare ac pervertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:37:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 37, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si res verba desideraret ac non pro se ipsa loqueretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: hoc te exspectare tempus tibi turpe est ac non ei rei sapientiā tuā te occurrere, Serv. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 5, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">velut destituti ac non qui ipsi destituissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 3</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si mihi mea sententia proferenda ac non disertissimorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.24" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">potius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quam ob rem scriba deducet, ac non potius mulio, qui advexit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 79</bibl></cit> (B. and K., <hi rend="ital">et</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">quis (eum) ita aspexit, ut perditum civem, ac non potius ut importunissimum hostem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 6, 12</bibl></cit>.— Pliny the elder commonly employs in this sense <hi rend="ital">atque non</hi>, not <hi rend="ital">ac non</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">concremāsse ea (scrinia) optumā fide atque non legisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 25, 26, § 94</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:108" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 24, 50, § 108</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:29" default="NO" valid="yes">29, 2, 9, § 29</bibl>; 27, 9, 55, § 78; 31, 7, 39, § 73 et saep. —</sense><sense id="n4275.25" n="IV" level="1"> In connecting clauses and beginning periods. </sense><sense id="n4275.26" n="1" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and too: Pamph.</hi> Antiquam adeo tuam venustatem obtines. <hi rend="ital">Bacch.</hi> Ac tu ecastor morem antiquom atque ingenium obtines, <hi rend="ital">And you too</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 4, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque illi (philosopho) ordiri placet etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:47:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 47, 183</bibl></cit>: Africanus indigens mei? Minime hercle. Ac ne ego quidem illius, <hi rend="ital">And I indeed not</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:9:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 9, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:11:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 11, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum versus facias, te ipsum percontor, etc. ... Atque ego cum Graecos facerem, natus mare citra, Versiculos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa quippe et diversa angebant: validior per Germaniam exercitus, etc. ... quos igitur anteferret? ac (i. e. similiter angebat), ne postpositi contumeliā incenderentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Minime, minime, inquit Secundus, atque adeo vellem maturius intervenisses,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ac similiter in translatione, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:77" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 77</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.27" n="2" level="3"> In adducing new arguments of similar force in favor of any assertion or making further statements about a subject, etc.; cf. Beier ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:11:487" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 11, 487</bibl>. </sense><sense id="n4275.28" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">maxima est enim vis vetustatis et consuetudinis: atque in ipso equo, cujus modo mentionem feci, si, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>and furthermore</tr>, <tr>and moreover</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:19:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 19, 68</bibl></cit>: Atque, si natura confirmatura jus non erit, <hi rend="ital">virtutes omnes</hi> tollentur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:15:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 15, 42</bibl> B. and K. —</sense><sense id="n4275.29" n="b" level="4"> Often with <hi rend="ital">etiam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque alias etiam dicendi virtutes sequitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:40:139" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 40, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque hoc etiam animadvertendum non esse omnia etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:61:251" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 61, 251</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26:90" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 26, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:11:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 11, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:2:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 2, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.30" n="c" level="4"> Sometimes with <hi rend="ital">quoque</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque occidi quoque Potius quam cibum praehiberem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 133</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:12:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 12, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:13:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 13, 3</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.31" n="d" level="4"> And even with <hi rend="ital">quoque etiam</hi>: Atque ego <pb n="191" /> <cb n="ATQU" /> quoque etiam, qui Jovis sum filius, Contagione etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 30</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.32" n="3" level="3"> In narration: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre submoventes obvios intrare portam, qui adducebant Philopoemenem, potuerunt: atque conferta turba iter reliquum clauserat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 21</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">completur caede, quantum inter castra murosque vacui fuit: ac rursus nova laborum facies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 30</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 28 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> and 2, 29 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n4275.33" n="4" level="3"> In introducing comparisons, <hi rend="ital">atque ut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">atque velut</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, esp. in epic poetry): <cit><quote lang="la">Atque ut perspicio, profecto etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ac veluti magno in populo cum saepe coörta est Seditio.... Sic cunctus pelagi cecidit fragor, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 148</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:170" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 170</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:626" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 626</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 402</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 441</bibl>; 6, 707; 9, 59; 10, 405; 10, 707; 10, 803; 11, 809; 12, 365; 12, 521; 12, 684; 12, 715; <cit><quote lang="la">12, 908: Inclinare meridiem Sentis ac, veluti stet volucris dies, Parcis deripere etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:28:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 28, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:664" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 664</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and so, Ac velut in nigro jactatis turbine nautis, etc. ... Tale fuit nobis Manius auxilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 63</bibl></cit> (for which Sillig and Müller read: <cit><quote lang="la">Hic velut, etc.): Atque ut magnas utilitates adipiscimur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:5:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque ut hujus mores veros amicos parere non potuerunt, sic etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:15:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 15, 54</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.34" n="5" level="3"> In connecting two acts or events. </sense><sense id="n4275.35" n="a" level="4"> In the order of time, <hi rend="ital">and then;</hi> hence the ancient grammarians assume in it the notion of quick succession, and explain it, though improperly, as syn. with statim, ilico, without any accompanying copulative, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 530, 1 sq.</bibl> (only in the poets and histt.): Atque atque accedit muros Romana juventus (the repetition of the atque represents the approach step by step), Enn. ap. Gell. and Non. l. l. (Ann. v. 527 Müll.): Quo imus unā; <cit><quote lang="la">ad prandium? Atque illi tacent,</quote> <trans><tr>And then they are silent</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ubi cenamus? inquam, atque illi abnuunt,</quote> <trans><tr>and upon this they shake their head</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum circumspecto atque ego lembum conspicor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 45</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 1, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucernam forte oblitus fueram exstinguere: Atque ille exclamat derepente maximum,</quote> <trans><tr>and then he suddenly exclaims</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 57</bibl></cit>: cui fidus Achates It comes ... atque illi Misenum in litore sicco Ut venere, vident, etc., <hi rend="ital">and as they thus came</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 162</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixerat, atque illi sese deus obtulit ultro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:481" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 481</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 360</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:39:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 39, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum Otho ingredi castra ausus: atque illum tribuni centurionesque circumsistunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 82</bibl></cit>. —Sometimes with two imperatives, in order to indicate vividly the necessity of a quicker succession, or the close connection between two actions: <cit><quote lang="la">cape hoc argentum atque defer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abi domum ac deos comprecare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tace modo ac sequere hac,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Accipe carmina atque hanc sine tempora circum hederam tibi serpere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 8, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 40</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 65</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 330</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Da auxilium, pater, atque haec omina firma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 691</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 89</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 250</bibl>; 3, 639; 4, 424; 9, 90; 10, 624; 11, 370.—</sense><sense id="n4275.36" n="b" level="4"> In the order of thought, <hi rend="ital">and so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and thus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and therefore.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4275.37" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si nunc de tuo jure concessisses paululum, Atque adulescenti morigerāsses,</quote> <trans><tr>and so</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.38" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ita</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ventum deinde ad multo angustiorem rupem, atque ita rectis saxis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 58, 79, § 158</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ac sic prope innumerabiles species reperiuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:67" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 67</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.39" n="c" level="4"> Connecting conclusion and condition, <hi rend="ital">so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then</hi> (cf. at, II. F.): <cit><quote lang="la">non aliter quam qui adverso vix flumine lembum Remigiis subigit, si bracchia forte remisit, Atque illum praeceps prono rapit alveus amni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 203</bibl></cit> (here explained by <hi rend="ital">statim</hi> by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 29</bibl>, and by Servius, but thus its connective force is wholly lost; cf. also Forbig ad h. l. for still another explanation).—</sense><sense id="n4275.40" n="6" level="3"> (As supra, I. c.) To annex a thought of more importance: <cit><quote lang="la">Satisne videtur declarāsse Dionysius nihil esse ei beatum, cui semper aliqui terror impendeat? atque ei ne integrum quidem erat, ut ad justitiam remigraret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:21:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 21, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,006:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tull. 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc enim spectant leges, hoc volunt, incolumem esse civium conjunctionem, quam qui dirimunt, eos morte ... coërcent. Atque hoc multo magis efficit ipsa naturae ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:5:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 5, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 1, 4</bibl>: hac spe lapsus Induciomarus ... exsules<cb n="ATQU" />  damnatosque totā Galliā magnis praemiis ad se allicere coepit; <cit><quote lang="la">ac tantam sibi jam iis rebus in Galliā auctoritatem comparaverat, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 55 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 13, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:10:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 10, 16</bibl>.—Hence also in answers, in order to confirm a question or assertion: <cit><quote lang="la">Sed videone ego Pamphilippum cum fratre Epignomo? Atque is est,</quote> <trans><tr>And he it is</tr>, <tr>Yes</tr>, <tr>it is he</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:4:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 24</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Mihin malum minitare? <hi rend="ital">Ca.</hi> Atque edepol non minitabor, sed dabo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 4, 4, 15</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Egon formidulosus? nemost hominum, qui vivat, minus. <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Atque ita opust, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.41" n="7" level="3"> In expressing a wish, atque utinam: <cit><quote lang="la">Veritus sum arbitros, atque utinam memet possim obliscier! Att., Trag. Rel. p. 160 Rib.: videmus enim fuisse quosdam, qui īdem ornate ac graviter, īdem versute et subtiliter dicerent. Atque utinam in Latinis talis oratoris simulacrum reperire possemus!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:7:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 7, 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:5:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 5, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque utinam pro decore etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:41:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 41, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque utinam ex vobis unus etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:575" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 575</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque utinam ... Ille vir in medio fiat amore lapis!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:9:47" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 9, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:6:15" default="NO">3, 6, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:7:25" default="NO">3, 7, 25</bibl>; 3, 8, 19 al.—</sense><sense id="n4275.42" n="8" level="3"> To connect an adversative clause, and often fully with tamen, <hi rend="ital">and yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">notwithstanding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nevertheless.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4275.43" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: Mihi quidem hercle non fit veri simile; <cit><quote lang="la">atque ipsis commentum placet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 20</bibl></cit> Ruhnk. (atque pro tamen, Don.): <cit><quote lang="la">ego quia non rediit filius, quae cogito! ... Atque ex me hic natus non est, sed ex fratre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 15</bibl></cit> (Quasi dicat, ex me non est, et sic afficior: quid paterer si genuissem? Don.; cf. Acron. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 204</bibl> P.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:11:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 11, 48</bibl> Beier; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:34:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 34, 71</bibl> Matth.: <cit><quote lang="la">ceterum ex aliis negotiis, quae ingenio exercentur, in primis magno usui est memoria rerum gestarum ... Atque ego credo fore qui, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>and yet I believe</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 4, 1</bibl></cit> and 3 Corte; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 51, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">observare principis egressum in publicum, insidere vias examina infantium futurusque populus solebat. Labor parentibus erat ostentare parvulos ... Ac plerique insitis precibus surdas principis aures obstrepebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:26" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.44" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">tamen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil praeterea est magnopere dicendum. Ac tamen, ne cui loco non videatur esse responsum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:27:85" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 27, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discipulos dissimilīs inter se ac tamen laudandos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:10:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 10, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:7:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 7, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque in his tamen tribus generibus etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:33:118" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 33, 118</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Prov. Cons. 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 15</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> (cf. in reference to the last four passages Wund. Varr. Lectt. p. lviii. sq.): <cit><quote lang="la">ac tamen initia fastigii etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 56</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 56</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">14, 21: pauciores cum pluribus certāsse, ac tamen fusos Germanos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 5, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.45" n="9" level="3"> To connect a minor affirmative proposition (the assumptio or propositio minor of logical lang.) in syllogisms, <hi rend="ital">now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but now</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">atqui</hi> is used to connect either an affirmative or negative minor premiss: v. atqui): Scaptius quaternas postulabat. Metui, si impetrāsset, ne tu ipse me amare desineres; <cit><quote lang="la">... Atque hoc tempore ipso impingit mihi epistulam etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes the conclusion is to be supplied: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi qui naturas hominum, penitus perspexerit, dicendo, quod volet, perficere non poterit. Atque totus hic locus philosophorum putatur proprius (conclusion: ergo oratorem philosophiam cognoscere oportet),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:12:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 12, 53</bibl></cit> and 54.—</sense><sense id="n4275.46" n="10" level="3"> In introducing a purpose (freq. in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n4275.47" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A negative purpose</hi>, and esp. in anticipating an objection: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne sine causā videretur edixisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 9, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne forte hoc magnum ac mirabile esse videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:46:191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 46, 191</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 12, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne saepius dicendum sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne forte roges, quo me duce, quo lare tuter,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne forte putes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 208</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac ne forte putes etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 465</bibl></cit> (Merkel, <hi rend="ital">Et</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n4275.48" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A positive purpose</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque ut ejus diversa studia in dissimili ratione perspicere possitis, nemo etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 5, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque ut omnes intellegant me etc. ... dico etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 8, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:14:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 14, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:11:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 11, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque ut C. Flaminium relinquam etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:9:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 9, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 2, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.49" n="11. a." level="1"> In continuing a thought in assertions or narration, <hi rend="ital">and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and now</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:prol. 18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. prol. 18</bibl>: audistis, cum pro se diceret, genus orationis, etc., ... perspexistis. Atque in eo non solum <cb n="ATQU" /> ingenium ejus videbatis, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:19:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 19, 45</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:32:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 32, 130</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 7, 27</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 10, 39 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 1</bibl>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Eum.</author> 10, 3</bibl> Bremi; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 64</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:1 al" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 1 al.</bibl>: ac si, sublato illo, depelli a vobis omne periculum judicarem, <hi rend="ital">now if I</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque si etiam hoc natura praescribit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:6:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 6, 27</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:2:8" default="NO">10, 2, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.50" n="b" level="4"> In introducing parentheses: <cit><quote lang="la">vulgo credere, Penino (atque inde nomen et jugo Alpium inditum) transgressum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omne adfectūs genus (atque ea maxime jucundam et ornatam faciunt orationem) de luxuriā, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:3:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 3, 15</bibl></cit> MSS., where Halm after Spalding reads <hi rend="ital">et quae.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n4275.51" n="c" level="4"> At the conclusion of a discourse (not infreq. in Cic.): Atque in primis duabus dicendi partibus qualis esset, summatim breviterque descripsimus, <hi rend="ital">And thus have we</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">briefly described</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:15:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 15, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac de primo quidem officii fonte diximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:6:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 6, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac de inferendā quidem injuriā satis dictum est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 8, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:39:115 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 39, 115 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4275.52" n="V" level="1"> In particular connections and phrases. </sense><sense id="n4275.53" n="A" level="2"> Unus atque alter, <hi rend="ital">one and the other;</hi> alius atque alius, <hi rend="ital">one and another; now this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now that</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">unae atque alterae scalae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 60:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 60, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quarum (coclearum) cum unam atque alteram, dein plures peteret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 93:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 93, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unum atque alterum lacum integer perfluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dilatisque aliā atque aliā de causā comitiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:23:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 23, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:8:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 8, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alius atque alius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 50</bibl> (v. alius, II. D.).—Also separated by several words: <cit><quote lang="la">aliud ejus subinde atque aliud facientes initium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 32:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 32, 2</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n4275.54" n="B" level="2"> Etiam atque etiam. <hi rend="ital">again and again</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">temo Stellas cogens etiam atque etiam Noctis sublime iter, Enn., Trag. Rel. p. 39 Rib.: etiam atque etiam cogita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam atque etiam considera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:14:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 14, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">monitos eos etiam atque etiam volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:12:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 12, 27</bibl></cit>.—So, semel atque iterum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 49</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 17</bibl>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">iterum atque iterum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:527" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 527</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 39</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.55" n="C" level="2"> Huc atque illuc, <hi rend="ital">hither and thither</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Rosc. 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:40:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 40, 184</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 357</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 376</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 85</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.56" n="D" level="2"> Longe atque late, <hi rend="ital">far and wide</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Marcell. 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque eccum or atque eccum video, in colloquial lang.: Heus vocate huc Davom. Atque eccum,</quote> <trans><tr>but here he is</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Audire vocem visa sum modo militis. Atque eccum,</quote> <trans><tr>and here he is</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.57" n="E" level="2"> Atque omnia, in making an assertion general, <hi rend="ital">and so generally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque in eis omnibus, quae sunt actionis, inest quaedam vis a naturā data,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:59:223" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 59, 223</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum (verborum) descriptus ordo alias aliā terminatione concluditur, atque omnia illa et prima et media verba spectare debent ad ultimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:59:200" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 59, 200</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:64:257" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 64, 257</bibl>: commoda civium non divellere, atque omnes aequitate eādem continere, <hi rend="ital">and so rather</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23:83" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 23, 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil acerbum esse, nihil crudele, atque omnia plena clementiae, humanitatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atque omnis vitae ratio sic constat, ut, quae probamus in aliis, facere ipsi velimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:2:2" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.58" n="F" level="1"> With other conjunctions. </sense><sense id="n4275.59" n="1" level="3"> After <hi rend="ital">et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equidem putabam virtutem hominibus instituendo et persuadendo, non minis et vi ac metu tradi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:58:247" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 58, 247</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Magnifica vero vox et magno viro ac sapiente digna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vanus aspectus et auri fulgor atque argenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 32</bibl></cit>.: <cit><quote lang="la">denuntiarent, ut ab Saguntinis abstineret et Carthaginem in Africam traicerent ac sociorum querimonias deferrent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi et fratrem consilii ac periculi socium haberem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:41:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 41, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et uti liter demum ac Latine perspicueque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nam et subtili plenius aliquid atque subtilius et vehementi remissius atque vehementius invenitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 10, 67</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n4275.60" n="2" level="3"> After <hi rend="ital">que</hi>, as in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">te\ kai/</foreign>: litterisque ac laudibus aeternare, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 75, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">submoverique atque in castra redigi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrorem caedemque ac fugam fecere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mus Sub terris posuitque domos atque horrea fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 182</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 434</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:486" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 8, 486</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.61" n="3" level="3"> Before <hi rend="ital">et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelum ipsum ac mare et silvas circum spectantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.62" n="4" level="3"> After <hi rend="ital">neque</hi> (only in the poets and post - Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">nec clavis nec canis atque calix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:32:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 32, 4</bibl></cit>: naturam Oceani atque aestūs<pb n="192" /> <cb n="ATQU" />  neque quaerere hujus operis est, ac multi retulere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mediocritatem pristinam neque dissimulavit umquam ac frequenter etiam prae se tulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4275.63" n="G" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Atque</hi> repeated, esp. in arch. Lat.: Scio solere plerisque hominibus in rebus secundis atque prolixis atque prosperis animum excellere atque superbiam atque ferociam augescere atque crescere, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 3</bibl>: Dicere possum quibus villae atque aedes aedificatae atque expolitae maximo opere citro atque ebore atque pavimentis Poenicis stent, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=242" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 242</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">atque ut C. Flamininum atque ea, quae jam prisca videntur, propter vetustatem relinquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:9:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 9, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnem dignitatem tuam in virtute atque in rebus gestis atque in tuā gravitate positam existimare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 5, 8</bibl></cit>.—Esp. freq. in enumerations in the poets: <cit><quote lang="la">Haec atque illa dies atque alia atque alia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 152</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Mavortia tellus Atque Getae atque Hebrus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:463" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 463</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Clioque et Beroë atque Ephyre Atque Opis et Asia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 343</bibl></cit>.—And sometimes forming a double connective, <hi rend="ital">both— and</hi> = et—et: <cit><quote lang="la">Multus ut in terras deplueretque lapis: Atque tubas atque arma ferunt crepitantia caelo Audita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:73" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">complexa sui corpus miserabile nati Atque deos atque astra vocat crudelia mater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:93" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 93</bibl>; v. Forbig ad Verg. l. l.!*? Atque regularly stands at the beginning of its sentence or clause or before the word it connects, but in poetry it sometimes, like et and at, stands: </sense><sense id="n4275.64" n="a" level="4"> In the second place: <cit><quote lang="la">Jamque novum terrae stupeant lucescere solem, Altius atque cadant imbres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 38</bibl></cit> Rib., ubi v. Forbig.: <cit><quote lang="la">Accipite ergo animis atque haec mea figite dicta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 250</bibl></cit>, and 10, 104 (animis may, however, here be taken with Accipite, as in <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 304</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">Esto beata, funus atque imagines Ducant triumphales tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:8:11" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 8, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 5, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 6, 111</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 7, 12</bibl> (ubi v. Fritzsche).—</sense><sense id="n4275.65" n="b" level="4"> In the third place: <cit><quote lang="la">quod pubes hederā virente Gaudeant pullā magis atque myrto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:25:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 25, 18</bibl></cit>; cf. at <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> (Vid. more upon this word in Hand, Turs. I. pp. 452-513.)</sense></entryFree>
